wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Coder Development Environment. Explain its purpose as a containerized development environment using VS Code Server (code-server) with support for both Docker and Singularity. Highlight the key features including pre-installed extensions (GitHub Copilot, Python, C/C++ tools), development tools (Node.js via nvm, Python with uv, Atlassian CLI), and cross-platform compatibility between local workstations and HPC environments. Describe the architectural intent of providing a consistent, reproducible development setup with user identity preservation and environment standardization. Include integration points such as X11 forwarding, proxy support, and file system mounts. Provide a high-level explanation of how components interact, including image building, container execution, and environment setup. Use terminology consistent with the codebase (e.g., 'coder.sif', 'setup_env_in_container.sh'). Offer a beginner-friendly summary of containerization concepts in context, and explain the value proposition for both new and experienced developers. Reference the README.md for core messaging and feature listing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Docker Execution
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Docker execution via run_coder_docker.sh. Explain how the script orchestrates container startup using docker run with critical flags: --user for UID/GID mapping to preserve file ownership, --security-opt seccomp=unconfined and --cap-add=SYS_ADMIN for privileged operations (e.g., FUSE mounting), --device /dev/fuse for file system in user space support, and --ipc=host for shared memory access required by GUI applications. Detail port exposure through -p $PORT:$PORT and -p $CODE_SERVER_PORT:$CODE_SERVER_PORT for web-based IDE access. Describe volume mounting strategy binding /nfs, /usr/intel, and /tmp/.X11-unix for resource sharing and X11 forwarding. Explain environment variable propagation (-e http_proxy, https_proxy, no_proxy, DISPLAY) for network and display configuration. Differentiate between service mode (default) and shell mode (--shell) execution paths. Provide real-world usage examples, including overriding PORT via environment variables. Illustrate data flow between host and container, emphasizing persistent storage and X11 socket forwarding. Address common issues such as port conflicts, missing X11 sockets, xhost permission denials, and fuse device access errors, with step-by-step resolution guidance. Discuss performance implications of bind mounts versus named volumes and security trade-offs of privileged flags in development contexts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Quick Start Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Quick Start Guide, focusing on enabling users to rapidly set up and access the development environment. Provide two clear pathways: Docker for local development and Singularity for HPC environments. For Docker, detail the steps to build the image using build_coder.sh and run the container via run_coder_docker.sh, specifying the required command-line execution and expected output. Include the exact URL (http://localhost:7860) for accessing the web-based IDE. For Singularity, outline the three-step process: building the Docker image, converting it to Singularity format using docker_to_singularity.sh, and executing run_coder_singularity.sh with optional custom home path. Use verbatim commands from the README.md and scripts. Explain prerequisites such as Docker/Singularity installation and submodule initialization. Include practical examples with code snippets, common pitfalls (e.g., missing coder.sif, port conflicts), and verification steps. Ensure the guide is accessible to beginners while providing enough technical detail for troubleshooting.

wiki_catalogs.name: Singularity Execution
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Singularity execution via run_coder_singularity.sh. Explain how the script runs the coder.sif image using singularity run and singularity shell, with emphasis on user-space execution model suitable for HPC environments. Detail the --home flag usage to redirect the container's HOME directory to a custom path (default: /nfs/site/home/$(whoami)/coder), enabling persistent configuration storage. Describe bind mounting strategy with --bind for /nfs, /tmp, /var/tmp, /tmp/.X11-unix, and /dev/fuse to ensure resource availability and GUI support. Explain environment variable forwarding via SINGULARITYENV_* prefixes (e.g., SINGULARITYENV_PORT, SINGULARITYENV_DISPLAY) to control application behavior inside the container. Cover X11 access management: automatic xhost +SI:localuser:$(whoami) or xhost +local: for local displays and network-aware hostname resolution for remote X servers, including pre-execution access grants and post-exit revocation. Document dependency on prior image conversion via docker_to_singularity.sh and error handling when coder.sif is missing. Provide usage examples including shell mode (--shell) for debugging and custom home directory specification. Address common runtime failures such as missing .Xauthority file, xhost permission issues, and bind mount path mismatches. Discuss performance characteristics of Singularity's native filesystem integration versus Docker, particularly in I/O-heavy development workflows on shared storage.

wiki_catalogs.name: Build System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the build system centered on build_coder.sh and the Dockerfile. Explain how build_coder.sh orchestrates the Docker image creation process by invoking docker build with appropriate build arguments for UID, GID, and proxy settings. Detail the role of the Dockerfile in defining the base image, installing system packages, setting up code-server, and copying setup scripts. Highlight key implementation details such as user creation with host-mapped IDs, environment variable propagation, and multi-stage considerations. Document configuration options including HTTP_PROXY, HTTPS_PROXY, and NO_PROXY support. Provide usage examples from the command line and explain the tagging convention (coder:latest). Discuss integration with other components—how the built image serves as the foundation for both Docker and Singularity workflows. Address common issues like proxy misconfiguration or permission errors during build, and offer debugging strategies such as inspecting Docker build output. Include performance considerations such as layer caching and image size optimization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Runtime Execution
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the runtime execution of the Coder environment, covering both Docker and Singularity execution models. For Docker execution via run_coder_docker.sh, explain how the script launches the container with critical flags: port mapping (7860), volume mounts (home, XDG, gitconfig), user namespace settings, and environment variable forwarding. Describe the security implications of --privileged and --ipc=host when needed for GUI applications. For Singularity execution via run_coder_singularity.sh, detail how it runs the coder.sif image with bind paths, custom HOME directory support, and preserved environment variables. Explain the differences in execution context between Docker (daemon-based) and Singularity (user-space, HPC-friendly). Provide concrete examples of command usage, including optional parameters like custom home paths. Illustrate data flow between host and container, especially file ownership and persistence. Address common runtime issues such as port conflicts, missing mounts, or X11 forwarding failures, and provide resolution steps. Discuss performance aspects like filesystem I/O overhead in containerized IDEs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Environment Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the environment configuration process managed by setup_env_in_container.sh and related scripts. Explain how this script is executed inside the container to install essential development tools: Node.js via nvm, Python's uv package manager, and Atlassian CLI. Detail the installation of VS Code extensions from the local vsix/ directory, including GitHub Copilot and language-specific tooling. Describe the one-time nature of this setup and its role in finalizing the development environment after container launch. Reference the specialized hf/install_vscode_copilot_chat.sh script for alternative Copilot Chat installation methods. Document configuration parameters such as extension versions and tool versions. Provide usage examples showing how to invoke the script within the running container. Explain integration with the Dockerfile and run scripts, particularly how the environment setup completes the provisioning chain. Address common issues like failed extension installations or network timeouts during tool downloads, and suggest solutions such as retrying or checking proxy settings.

wiki_catalogs.name: Conversion Process (Docker to Singularity)
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Docker to Singularity conversion process using docker_to_singularity.sh. Explain the purpose of this script in enabling HPC compatibility by transforming the Docker image (coder:latest) into a Singularity image file (coder.sif). Detail the technical workflow: stopping any running containers, exporting the Docker image via docker save, and using singularity build to convert the tar stream into a SIF file. Highlight error handling mechanisms such as exit code checking and status messaging. Document prerequisites including Docker and Singularity installations, and the necessity of building the Docker image first. Provide a step-by-step example of the conversion process with expected output and file creation. Explain integration points—how the output .sif file is consumed by run_coder_singularity.sh. Address common issues like missing singularity command, insufficient disk space, or Docker image not found, and offer troubleshooting guidance. Discuss performance considerations such as conversion time and resulting image size.

wiki_catalogs.name: Container Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the container design based on Dockerfile and hf/Dockerfile. Describe the high-level structure of the base image, including the choice of Ubuntu LTS as the base OS and the installation of core dependencies (curl, git, sudo, etc.). Explain the layered approach: system packages, code-server installation, user setup with UID/GID mapping, and script copying. Compare the main Dockerfile with the alternative in hf/ directory, noting differences in configuration or tooling. Document the use of environment variables for customization and proxy support. Illustrate component interactions: how the Dockerfile defines the image that is built by build_coder.sh and executed by run scripts. Address security considerations such as non-root user execution and minimal privilege principles. Include infrastructure requirements like disk space, memory, and network access during build. Discuss scalability in team environments where multiple developers use the same image. Provide insights into design trade-offs, such as bundling tools vs. runtime installation, and constraints imposed by HPC environments requiring Singularity compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Customization Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for customizing the Coder development environment. Cover key extension points: adding new VS Code extensions by placing .vsix files in the vsix/ directory and modifying setup_env_in_container.sh to install them; changing the exposed port by editing the -p flag in run_coder_docker.sh; and adding custom volume mounts using -v flags in the run scripts. Explain how to extend the Dockerfile to install additional system packages or development tools. Detail how to customize user environment variables, git configuration, or shell settings through modifications to setup scripts or mounted dotfiles. Provide practical examples such as installing a new language server or integrating with a corporate authentication system. Discuss integration with external tools and services via environment variables or mounted credentials. Address common customization pitfalls like breaking the build process or causing permission conflicts. Offer best practices for maintaining customizations across updates, such as using version control for modified scripts. Include performance implications of adding heavy tools or large extensions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Troubleshooting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive troubleshooting documentation covering common issues encountered when using the Coder environment. Organize by category: Docker issues (daemon not running, port 7860 in use, proxy misconfiguration), Singularity issues (missing coder.sif, Singularity not installed, mount path errors), permission problems (incorrect file ownership due to UID/GID mismatch), and network access (firewall blocking port 7860, remote access via SSH tunneling). For each issue, provide the symptom, root cause analysis, and step-by-step resolution. Use real examples from the codebase, such as checking output from build_coder.sh for proxy errors or verifying coder.sif existence before running Singularity. Include diagnostic commands like docker images, singularity inspect, or ps aux inside the container. Reference error messages likely to appear in logs. Address environment-specific challenges such as corporate firewalls requiring proxy settings in both build and run scripts. Offer prevention strategies like always rebuilding after UID changes. Include performance-related troubleshooting such as slow extension installation or high memory usage.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Coder Development Environment

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
This project provides a containerized development environment using VS Code Server (code-server) with comprehensive tooling for software development. The environment is designed to be consistent across different platforms and supports both Docker and Singularity container runtimes.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Provide a standardized development environment with pre-installed tools and extensions
- Support both local development (via Docker) and HPC environments (via Singularity)
- Preserve user identity and file permissions across container boundaries
- Include essential development tools for Python, Node.js, C++ and web development

### Target Audience
The primary audience includes developers working in mixed environments, particularly those who need to transition between local development workstations and high-performance computing (HPC) environments that require Singularity containers.

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The architecture consists of a base container image with multiple supporting scripts that handle building, running, and converting the container environment.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Base Ubuntu 24.04] --> B[Docker Image]
    B --> C[VS Code Server]
    B --> D[Development Tools]
    D --> D1[Node.js via nvm]
    D --> D2[Python with uv]
    D --> D3[Atlassian CLI]
    B --> E[VS Code Extensions]
    E --> E1[GitHub Copilot]
    E --> E2[Python Tools]
    E --> E3[C/C++ Tools]
    B --> F[Build Scripts]
    F --> G[build_coder.sh]
    F --> H[run_coder_docker.sh]
    F --> I[docker_to_singularity.sh]
    F --> J[run_coder_singularity.sh]
```

### Design Patterns
The project employs several key design patterns:
- **Containerization**: Using Docker as the primary container format with Singularity conversion capability
- **Configuration as Code**: All environment setup is scripted and reproducible
- **Multi-stage Environment Setup**: Separation between image building and runtime environment configuration
- **User Identity Preservation**: Maintaining host user IDs within containers for proper file ownership

### System Relationships
The components interact through a clear hierarchy where the Dockerfile defines the base environment, build scripts create the container image, and runtime scripts execute the environment with appropriate configurations.

```mermaid
graph TD
    Dockerfile --> build_coder.sh
    build_coder.sh --> coder:latest
    coder:latest --> run_coder_docker.sh
    coder:latest --> docker_to_singularity.sh
    docker_to_singularity.sh --> coder.sif
    coder.sif --> run_coder_singularity.sh
    setup_env_in_container.sh --> InsideContainer
```

### Data Flow
```mermaid
flowchart LR
    SourceCode --> Dockerfile
    Dockerfile --> DockerImage
    DockerImage --> SingularityImage
    HostSystem --> Mounts
    Mounts --> DockerContainer
    Mounts --> SingularityContainer
    User --> Browser --> CodeServer
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- **Dockerfile**: Main container definition and base environment setup
- **scripts/build_coder.sh**: Script to build the Docker image
- **scripts/run_coder_docker.sh**: Script to run the Docker container
- **scripts/docker_to_singularity.sh**: Script to convert Docker image to Singularity format
- **scripts/run_coder_singularity.sh**: Script to run the Singularity container

### Core Modules
- **Container Configuration**: Defined in Dockerfile with system packages and tool installation
- **Environment Setup**: Handled by setup_env_in_container.sh for post-container setup
- **Runtime Execution**: Managed by run scripts that handle container execution parameters

### Configuration Approach
The project uses environment variables and build arguments to customize the container behavior, including user identity preservation and proxy configuration.

Sources:
- [Dockerfile](coder/Dockerfile)
- [build_coder.sh](coder/scripts/build_coder.sh)

### External Dependencies
- **Docker**: Container runtime for local development
- **Singularity**: Container runtime for HPC environments
- **code-server**: VS Code Server for web-based IDE
- **Node.js**: JavaScript runtime installed via nvm
- **Python**: Programming language with associated packages
- **Atlassian CLI**: Command-line interface for Jira and Confluence

### Integration Points
- **X11 Forwarding**: For GUI application support within containers
- **Network Ports**: Port 7860 exposed for code-server access
- **File System Mounts**: Home directories and system paths mounted into containers
- **Proxy Support**: HTTP proxy configuration passed to containers

### Component Relationships
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Dockerfile] --> B[coder:latest]
    C[build_coder.sh] --> B
    B --> D[run_coder_docker.sh]
    B --> E[docker_to_singularity.sh]
    E --> F[coder.sif]
    F --> G[run_coder_singularity.sh]
    H[setup_env_in_container.sh] --> I[Container Environment]
    D --> I
    G --> I
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The development environment provides a complete IDE experience through a web browser with access to all standard development tools. It supports both interactive shell access and direct IDE access.

### Implementation Highlights
- **User Identity Preservation**: The build script passes host user ID and group ID to the container
- **Dual Container Support**: Works with both Docker and Singularity runtimes
- **Pre-installed Extensions**: Includes GitHub Copilot, Python, and C++ extensions
- **Development Toolchain**: Comprehensive set of tools for multiple programming languages

### Feature Architecture
```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Build
    Build --> Docker: build_coder.sh
    Docker --> Singularity: docker_to_singularity.sh
    Docker --> RunDocker: run_coder_docker.sh
    Singularity --> RunSingularity: run_coder_singularity.sh
    RunDocker --> Access: http://localhost:7860
    RunSingularity --> Access
    Build --> Setup: setup_env_in_container.sh
    Setup --> Complete
    Access --> ActiveDevelopment
    ActiveDevelopment --> [*]
```

Sources:
- [README.md](coder/README.md)
- [Dockerfile](coder/Dockerfile)
- [build_coder.sh](coder/scripts/build_coder.sh)
- [run_coder_docker.sh](coder/scripts/run_coder_docker.sh)
- [docker_to_singularity.sh](coder/scripts/docker_to_singularity.sh)
- [run_coder_singularity.sh](coder/scripts/run_coder_singularity.sh)
- [setup_env_in_container.sh](coder/scripts/setup_env_in_container.sh)
- [hf/Dockerfile](coder/hf/Dockerfile)
- [hf/install_vscode_copilot_chat.sh](coder/hf/install_vscode_copilot_chat.sh)
</blog>

wiki_repo.name: coder
